children.value:
Source plugin for pulling content types, entries, and assets into Gatsby from
Contentful spaces. It creates links between entry types and asset so they can be
queried in Gatsby using GraphQL.
An example site for using this plugin is at
First, you need a way to pass environment variables to the build process, so secrets and other secured data arenâ€™t committed to source control. We recommend using
which will then expose environment variables.
Read more about dotenv and using environment variables here
these environment variables and configure our plugin.

// In your gatsby-config.js
module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-source-contentful`,
      options: {
        spaceId: `your_space_id`,
        // Learn about environment variables: https://gatsby.app/env-vars
        accessToken: process.env.CONTENTFUL_ACCESS_TOKEN,
      },
    },
  ],
}

// In your gatsby-config.js
module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-source-contentful`,
      options: {
        spaceId: `your_space_id`,
        // Learn about environment variables: https://gatsby.app/env-vars
        accessToken: process.env.CONTENTFUL_ACCESS_TOKEN,
        host: `preview.contentful.com`,
      },
    },
  ],
}
If you donâ€™t have internet connection you can add
to tell the plugin to fallback to the cached data, if there is any.
Contentful delivery api key, when using the Preview API use your Preview API key
The base host for all the API requests, by default itâ€™s â€˜cdn.contentful.comâ€™, if you want to use the Preview API set it to
. You can use your own host for debugging/testing purposes as long as you respect the same Contentful JSON structure.
The environment to pull the content from, for more info on environments check out this
You can pass in any other options available in the

hProperties.aria-label: notes on contentful content models permalink

children.value: There are currently some things to keep in mind when building your content models at Contentful.
At the moment, fields that do not have at least one populated instance will not be created in the GraphQL schema.

When using reference fields, be aware that this source plugin will automatically create the reverse reference. You do not need to create references on both content types. For simplicity, it is easier to put the reference field on the child in child/parent relationships.

hProperties.aria-label: how to query for nodes permalink

children.value: Two standard node types are available from Contentful:
nodes will be created in your siteâ€™s GraphQL schema under
nodes are a little different - their exact name depends on what you called them in your Contentful data models. The nodes will be created in your siteâ€™s GraphQL schema under
In all cases querying for nodes like
will return a single node, and nodes like
will return all nodes of that type.

{
  allContentfulAsset {
    edges {
      node {
        id
        file {
          url
        }
      }
    }
  }
}
You might do this in your

hProperties.aria-label: query for a single node permalink

children.value: asset with the title â€˜fooâ€™ and a width of 1600px:

export const assetQuery = graphql`
  {
    contentfulAsset(filter: { title: { eq: 'foo' } }) {
      image {
        resolutions(width: 1600) {
          width
          height
          src
          srcSet
        }
      }
    }
  }
`
node with the short text properties

{
    contentfulCaseStudy(filter: { title: { eq: 'bar' } })  {
      title
      subtitle
    }
  }
Gatsbyâ€™s GraphQL reference docs for more info
node inside a component in your

hProperties.aria-label: a note about longtext fields permalink

children.value: If you include fields with a
. This is because Contentful LongText fields are Markdown by default. In order to handle the Markdown content properly, this field type is created as a child node so Gatsby can transform it to HTML.
type fields will be returned as strings.
requires formatting the LongText fields as an object with the
child node containing the exact same field name as the parent

{
  contentfulCaseStudy {
    title
    subtitle
    body {
      body
    }
  }
}
When Contentful pulls the data, all localizations will be pulled. Therefore, if you have a localization active, it will duplicate the entries. Narrow the search by filtering the query with

{
  allContentfulCaseStudy(filter: { node_locale: { eq: "en-US" } }) {
    edges {
      node {
        id
        slug
        title
        subtitle
        body {
          body
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

hProperties.aria-label: query for assets in contenttype nodes permalink

children.value: Query for Assets in ContentType nodes
nodes will be mixed inside of your
nodes, so youâ€™ll query them together. All the same formatting rules for
to return all instances of that

{
  allContentfulCaseStudy {
    edges {
      node {
        id
        slug
        title
        subtitle
        body {
          body
        }
        heroImage {
          resolutions(width: 1600) {
            width
            height
            src
            srcSet
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

hProperties.aria-label: more on queries with contentful and gatsby permalink

children.value: More on Queries with Contentful and Gatsby

It is strongly recommended that you take a look at how data flows in a real Contentful and Gatsby application to fully understand how the queries, Node.js functions and React components all come together. Check out the example site at
Rich text feature is supported in this source plugin, if you want to serialize the field content to html you can add the plugin
After adding the transformer plugin you can use the following query to get the html output:

{
  allContentfulBlogPost {
    bodyRichText {
      childContentfulRichText {
        html
      }
    }
  }
}
